awd_titl_txt: RI:Small: Leveraging Human Manipulation Skills to Advance Near Contact Robotic Grasping and In-Hand Stabilization
awd_abstract_narration:
People are incredibly good at picking up and manipulating objects. Robots, however, still struggle with reliably picking up objects. The goal of this project is to improve robotic grasping by observing how humans respond to challenging grasping situations. The project's central idea is that humans strive for grasp success rather than trying to find the best possible grasp.  Humans use a grasp that is likely to work, even if they have misjudged where the object is, what shape it is, how heavy it is, etc. Finding what these strategies are (in a form a robot can use) will improve robotic grasping in the "real world". 

The technical challenge addressed in this project is how to go from human demonstrations all the way to robot hand control strategies. First, human user study participants will demonstrate grasping with actual robotic hands by "puppeteering" the hands through a structured set of grasping and manipulation tasks. This demonstration will then be reconstructed in a physics simulator. This provides a rich set of data in an environment - grounded in physical reality - that algorithms can learn in. Finally, the data is put in a novel form that is ideally suited to capturing what happens as the hand comes into contact with the object in a form suitable for machine learning. The result is a learned set of near-contact robotic controllers that can be incorporated into existing grasp planning algorithms in order to improve robotic grasping.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This NSF grant has laid a strong foundation for research and development in the domain of robotic manipulation.  Specifically, it brings together a simultaneous exploration of the manipulation capability of various combinations of robotic hands, controllers, and controller development methods.  Extensive simulation and physical testbeds are utilized.  This work has yielded the following outcomes, categorized as intellectual merit and broader impacts. 

  

Intellectual merit 

1. The development of benchmarks for (i) comparing the dimensions of robot hands, since size affects manipulation capability; (ii) assessing in-hand object manipulation (the Asterisk test) 

2. The development of a method for the parameterization of robot hand designs that enables the generation of a different robot finger types (differing numbers of links, link sizes, link joints) 

3. The exploration through computer simulation and physical testbeds of planar object manipulation using robotic fingers with varied designs and controllers.  Varying the robot designs and controllers enabled a study of the effect of each variable (design and controller) on the robot’s performance. 

  • Robot designs considered include the following:  
  • Asymmetric two-finger robot hands where each finger may have two links or three links 
  • Two-finger robot hands where fingers have the same number of links but may have different link lengths.  
  • Robot controllers considered include the following: 
  • Human-guided control, where the participants manually guided the fingers 
  • Inverse-kinematics based control 
  • Reinforcement Learning-based control (Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient-- DDPG) 
4. Exploration of the robustness of reinforcement learning-based control policies when transferred verbatim from one robot design to another (zero-shot learning) and from simulation to the real world (sim2real). 
  • Specifically, the choice state and action space used during the training of the policy affects the robustness of transferring policies from simulation to real world and also between robot designs.  Using a design-agnostic state space and action space enables more robustness when transferring between designs.  However, when transferring from sim2real, having full state space information improves performance. 
5. All the above findings/contributions have been captured in published papers or in papers under review (see products). 
6. Three PhD students, six MS students, 2 MS/Ugrads, 6 undergraduate, and 3 REU students were trained during this project. 

 

Broader impacts 

1. The integration of approaches from traditional control, human-guided control, and machine learning domains to develop robot manipulation strategies.  The methods from each domain have strengths and weaknesses.  This project enables us to identify approaches to overcome weaknesses in each method.  For example, traditional control techniques can provide one solution with minimal data.  This solution can be compared with the solutions generated by machine learning techniques with significant amounts of data. 

2. The training of students (PhD, MS, and undergraduate) in an interdisciplinary research domain (traditional control, human-guided solutions, machine learning) and using computer simulation and physical testbeds for validation. 

3. The research findings will also enable the development of robotic manipulation algorithms for other domains such as robotic fruit picking and robotic surgery. 

4. The Robot Hand Dimensions benchmark is shared with the robotics community through GitHub: https://github.com/OSUrobotics/Applied-Hand-Dimensions  

 


Last Modified: 02/27/2024
Modified by: Ravi Balasubramanian
por.por_txt_cntn:
This NSF grant has laid a strong foundation for research and development in the domain of robotic manipulation. Specifically, it brings together a simultaneous exploration of the manipulation capability of various combinations of robotic hands, controllers, and controller development methods. Extensive simulation and physical testbeds are utilized. This work has yielded the following outcomes, categorized as intellectual merit and broader impacts.









Intellectual merit


1. The development of benchmarks for (i) comparing the dimensions of robot hands, since size affects manipulation capability; (ii) assessing in-hand object manipulation (the Asterisk test)


2. The development of a method for the parameterization of robot hand designs that enables the generation of a different robot finger types (differing numbers of links, link sizes, link joints)


3. The exploration through computer simulation and physical testbeds of planar object manipulation using robotic fingers with varied designs and controllers. Varying the robot designs and controllers enabled a study of the effect of each variable (design and controller) on the robots performance.



Robot designs considered include the following:
 Asymmetric two-finger robot hands where each finger may have two links or three links
 Two-finger robot hands where fingers have the same number of links but may have different link lengths.
Robot controllers considered include the following:
 Human-guided control, where the participants manually guided the fingers
 Inverse-kinematics based control
 Reinforcement Learning-based control (Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient-- DDPG)


4. Exploration of the robustness of reinforcement learning-based control policies when transferred verbatim from one robot design to another (zero-shot learning) and from simulation to the real world (sim2real).


Specifically, the choice state and action space used during the training of the policy affects the robustness of transferring policies from simulation to real world and also between robot designs. Using a design-agnostic state space and action space enables more robustness when transferring between designs. However, when transferring from sim2real, having full state space information improves performance.


5. All the above findings/contributions have been captured in published papers or in papers under review (see products).
6. Three PhD students, six MS students, 2 MS/Ugrads, 6 undergraduate, and 3 REU students were trained during this project.








Broader impacts


1. The integration of approaches from traditional control, human-guided control, and machine learning domains to develop robot manipulation strategies. The methods from each domain have strengths and weaknesses. This project enables us to identify approaches to overcome weaknesses in each method. For example, traditional control techniques can provide one solution with minimal data. This solution can be compared with the solutions generated by machine learning techniques with significant amounts of data.


2. The training of students (PhD, MS, and undergraduate) in an interdisciplinary research domain (traditional control, human-guided solutions, machine learning) and using computer simulation and physical testbeds for validation.


3. The research findings will also enable the development of robotic manipulation algorithms for other domains such as robotic fruit picking and robotic surgery.


4. The Robot Hand Dimensions benchmark is shared with the robotics community through GitHub: https://github.com/OSUrobotics/Applied-Hand-Dimensions
